abstract: Fannie Mae is in talks with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and IndyMac to force it to buy back certain mortgages.
snippet: Fannie Mae is in talks with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and IndyMac to force it to buy back certain mortgages.
lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae is in talks with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and IndyMac to force it to buy back certain mortgages. The discussions involve IndyMac loans sold to Fannie Mae and currently serviced by the bank, according to a statement from the Fannie Mae, the mortgage finance company that was taken over by the F.D.I.C. Regulators seized IndyMac in July after overdue mortgages left it short of cash, leading to a run on deposits. Fannie Mae also is working with the F.D.I.C. to resolve issues related to mortgages bought after the F.D.I.C. took control, Brian Faith, a Fannie Mae spokesman, said in the statement. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac want lenders to repurchase $1 billion to $10 billion in loans that violated their so-called representation and warranty agreements.

headline.main: Fannie Mae Seeks to Force Mortgage Buyback
headline.print_headline: Fannie Mae Seeks To Force Mortgage Buyback

abstract: MGA Entertainment lost a bid to extend a freeze on a court-ordered ban on manufacturing and selling the Bratz dolls while it appeals a jury verdict.
snippet: MGA Entertainment lost a bid to extend a freeze on a court-ordered ban on manufacturing and selling the Bratz dolls while it appeals a jury verdict.
lead_paragraph: MGA Entertainment lost a bid to extend a freeze on a court-ordered ban on manufacturing and selling the Bratz dolls while it appeals a jury verdict that the toys infringed on copyrights held by Mattel. United States District Judge Stephen Larson denied MGA’s request, saying it was premature while he was considering post-trial motions to be argued at a Feb. 11 hearing. On Jan. 5, the judge will hold a separate hearing at which MGA lawyers said he would consider extending the delay at least to the end of 2009 instead. Judge Larson ruled on Dec. 3 that MGA may no longer make most of the Bratz dolls that have contributed to a drop in Mattel’s Barbie sales since they were first brought on the market in 2001. A jury earlier found that a Mattel designer had come up with the Bratz name and characters and secretly had taken the idea to MGA.

headline.main: Judge Denies MGA’s Request on Bratz Dolls
headline.print_headline: Judge Denies MGA’s Request On Bratz Dolls

abstract: The Swiss bank agreed to sell a stake in its global investors business to Aberdeen Asset Management for 250 million British pounds ($361 million) in stock after losses at the unit.
snippet: The Swiss bank agreed to sell a stake in its global investors business to Aberdeen Asset Management for 250 million British pounds ($361 million) in stock after losses at the unit.
lead_paragraph: The Credit Suisse Group, the Swiss bank, agreed to sell a stake in its global investors business to Aberdeen Asset Management for 250 million British pounds ($361 million) in stock after losses at the unit. The stake includes assets under management of about 75 billion Swiss francs ($71 billion) and divisions in Europe, the United States and Asia, Credit Suisse said. Credit Suisse, which is based in Zurich, will receive a stake of almost 25 percent in the Aberdeen Asset Management firm and a seat on its board. The sale “enables us to focus our resources on alternative investments, asset allocation and Swiss businesses,” said Rob Shafir, chief executive officer of Credit Suisse’s asset management unit.

headline.main: Switzerland: Credit Suisse to Sell Stake
headline.print_headline: SWITZERLAND: CREDIT SUISSE TO SELL STAKE

abstract: India’s exports fell for a second consecutive month, adding pressure on the central bank to cut interest rates.
snippet: India’s exports fell for a second consecutive month, adding pressure on the central bank to cut interest rates.
lead_paragraph: India’s exports fell for a second consecutive month, adding pressure on the central bank to cut interest rates. Overseas shipments dropped 9.9 percent, to $11.5 billion, from a year earlier after contracting 12.1 percent in October, the first decline in seven years, the government said. “The negative news on the external side intensifies pressure on the Reserve Bank to cut rates to stoke domestic demand,” said Prasanna Ananthasubramaniam, an analyst at ICICI Securities in Mumbai.

headline.main: India: Exports Fall for a Second Month
headline.print_headline: INDIA: EXPORTS FALL FOR A SECOND MONTH

abstract: Hungary’s current-account deficit widened more than expected in the third quarter as imports increased faster than exports and investors took money out of the country.
snippet: Hungary’s current-account deficit widened more than expected in the third quarter as imports increased faster than exports and investors took money out of the country.
lead_paragraph: Hungary’s current-account deficit widened more than expected in the third quarter from the comparable period a year earlier as imports increased faster than exports and investors took money out of the country. The deficit was 2.49 billion euros ($3.5 billion), compared with 1.68 billion euros in the third quarter of 2007, the central bank said on Wednesday. The second-quarter deficit was revised to 1.95 billion euros. Hungary’s current account  a measure of the difference between money flowing into the country from trade, investment and services like tourism, and funds going out  widened as demand for the nation’s goods fell because of the global economic slump, and as international investors withdrew money from riskier emerging markets.

headline.main: Hungary: Quarterly Trade Deficit Grows
headline.print_headline: HUNGARY: QUARTERLY TRADE DEFICIT GROWS

abstract: Australia is beginning a spending program of 17 billion Australian dollars ($11.8 billion) to stimulate the economy amid the global financial crisis.
snippet: Australia is beginning a spending program of 17 billion Australian dollars ($11.8 billion) to stimulate the economy amid the global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Australia is beginning a spending program of 17 billion Australian dollars ($11.8 billion) to stimulate the economy amid the global financial crisis, the nation’s treasurer, Wayne Swan, left, said. The previously announced money will go to pensioners, families and first-time home buyers in addition to education, health and transport projects. The program comes after Australia’s economy expanded at its weakest rate in eight years in the third quarter.

headline.main: Australia: Stimulus Program Begins

And one clothing chain, not to be outdone, has started offering three suits for the price of one.

abstract: The agreement settles claims in California that the company had engaged in deceptive marketing of loans to customers against their expected tax refunds.
snippet: The agreement settles claims in California that the company had engaged in deceptive marketing of loans to customers against their expected tax refunds.
lead_paragraph: H & R Block, the biggest tax preparer in the United States, agreed to pay $4.85 million to settle claims in California that it had engaged in deceptive marketing of loans to customers against their expected tax refunds. The lawsuit, filed in 2006, took aim at H & R Block’s marketing and “cross collection,” when a client’s tax refund is withheld by a bank to pay debt from a previous loan. The agreement prohibits H & R Block from selling the so-called refund-anticipation loans as early tax refunds, the California attorney general, Jerry Brown, left, said. H & R Block denies any wrongdoing, Mr. Brown said. Nancy Mays, a company spokeswoman, declined to comment.

headline.main: H & R Block to Settle Marketing Case for $4.85 Million
headline.print_headline: H & R Block To Settle Marketing Case For $4.85. Million

abstract: The department-store company will stop matching contributions to its workers’ retirement plans on Jan. 31.
snippet: The department-store company will stop matching contributions to its workers’ retirement plans on Jan. 31.
lead_paragraph: The Sears Holdings Corporation, the department-store company, will stop matching contributions to its workers’ retirement plans on Jan. 31. The company will resume its 401(k) matching program when its “financial performance improves to a level adequate to support” it, a spokeswoman, Kimberly Freely, said. Sears recorded a $91 million expense for retirement savings plans in 2007, according to an annual report it filed on March 26. Ms. Freely declined to estimate how much the company would save by not matching employee contributions. Sears shares closed at $41.49, up $2.62, or 6.7 percent.

headline.main: Sears to Suspend Matching Contributions to 401(k)’s
headline.print_headline: Sears To Suspend Matching Contributions To 401(k)’s

abstract: The country’s trade surplus narrowed to a six-year low in 2008, propelled by a deepening economic slowdown that curbed demand for exports.
snippet: The country’s trade surplus narrowed to a six-year low in 2008, propelled by a deepening economic slowdown that curbed demand for exports.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s currency fell as the country’s trade surplus narrowed to a six-year low in 2008, propelled by a deepening economic slowdown that curbed demand for exports. The currency, the real, declined 0.1 percent, to 2.3176 per dollar from 2.3145 on Wednesday. It fell 23 percent last year. Brazil’s surplus shrank to $24.7 billion from $40 billion in 2007, the trade ministry said in a report on its Web site. It was the smallest surplus since a $13.1 billion reading in 2002. “Brazil is probably going to have a weak trade balance,” said Pedro Tuesta, an economist at 4Cast in Washington. The yield on Brazil’s overnight futures contract for January 2010 was little changed at 12.16 percent.

headline.main: Brazil’s Currency Falls as Trade Surplus Narrows
headline.print_headline: Brazil’s Currency Falls as Trade Surplus Narrows

lead_paragraph: Google Trends, a service that shows the relative popularity of search terms, fell victim to what appeared to be an ugly stunt on Tuesday: a sketch of an airplane flying into two towers appeared as its second most popular item under Hot Trends, its list of the fastest-rising searches at any given moment. TechCrunch and Search Engine Land both grabbed screen shots of the Google Trends page before the offending query receded in popularity later in the day.

snippet: Garmin, a maker of GPS devices, rolls out a new gadget to help golfers calculate distances and select the best club.
lead_paragraph: In this deteriorating economy, even the makers of GPS devices can’t find their way. The stock of Garmin, the Kansas City-based developer of technologies using the global positioning system, has fallen more than 75 percent in the last year. People are buying fewer devices and the company is slashing its prices and depressing its profit margins as a result. And mobile phone makers have mounted a growing challenge, giving away free location tools in handsets like the Apple iPhone.

abstract: Rambus, a designer of high-speed memory chips, may not use 12 of its patents to demand royalties from Micron Technology, a federal judge ruled.
snippet: Rambus, a designer of high-speed memory chips, may not use 12 of its patents to demand royalties from Micron Technology, a federal judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: Rambus, a designer of high-speed memory chips, may not use 12 of its patents to demand royalties from Micron Technology, a federal judge ruled. Judge Sue L. Robinson of United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., said the patents were unenforceable because Rambus destroyed documents, and called Rambus’s conduct “obstructive at best, misleading at worst.” Rambus said it would appeal. The decision could affect Rambus’s ability to use the patents against other companies to obtain royalties, and might delay a trial set to begin Jan. 19, in which chip makers including Micron and Samsung Electronics are challenging 10 Rambus patents. Rambus fell $7.26, or 39 percent, to $11.24, its largest plunge since going public in 1997.

headline.main: Chip Maker Rambus Loses Patent Case to Micron

abstract: While some doubt the wisdom of Yahoo’s selection of Carol Bartz as chief executive, the move would actually seem to be a logical step, assuming most shareholders would still like to see a full-blown deal with Microsoft. Ms. Bartz brings technology credentials solid enough to make her a credible candidate and has worked for enough different companies that she should be able to maintain the strategic detachment that will be required. But perhaps even more important, she apparently has no poisonous past with Steve Ballmer of Microsoft, who just can’t seem to resist letting people know just how personal it got between him and Jerry Yang, Ms. Bartz’s predecessor.
lead_paragraph: While some doubt the wisdom of Yahoo’s selection of Carol Bartz as chief executive, the move would actually seem to be a logical step, assuming most shareholders would still like to see a full-blown deal with Microsoft. But perhaps even more important, she apparently has no poisonous past with Steve Ballmer of Microsoft, who just can’t seem to resist letting people know just how personal it got between him and Jerry Yang, Ms. Bartz’s predecessor.

Rather than creating their own products, financial services firms, hedge funds and others can pick up the Marketcetera Platform software and use it as a basic framework for their operations. The financial companies just plug their algorithms and trading policies into the system and let it handle the demanding processing jobs required to obtain and analyze financial data.

abstract: Like it did with Terry Semel, Yahoo’s board chose Carol Bartz for her management expertise, not her familiarity with its lines of business.

lead_paragraph: I’ve got two thoughts on the selection of Carol Bartz as chief executive of Yahoo. First, Yahoo’s board appears to have selected her for exactly the same reasons it chose Terry Semel. Second, her first big test will be a decision on whether to outsource Yahoo’s search operation to Microsoft. I’m not as convinced this is a good idea as many analysts and observers are.

headline.main: Is Carol Bartz Terry Semel 2.0?

abstract: Close watchers of the eighth season premiere of “American Idol” might have noticed that Bikini Girl had blond hair in the crowd shots, but brown hair now. How?
snippet: Close watchers of the eighth season premiere of “American Idol” might have noticed that Bikini Girl had blond hair in the crowd shots, but brown hair now. How?
lead_paragraph: Hair color might have been the last thing that many viewers noticed about Bikini Girl during her appearance on the eighth season premiere of Fox’s “American Idol” on Tuesday. But close watchers of the crowd shots that opened the eighth season premiere of the biggest show on television might have noticed that Bikini Girl, also known as Katrina Darrell of Chino Hills, Calif., had blond hair when she joined thousands of other “Idol” aspirants in the Jobing.com Arena in Glendale, Ariz., in July.

headline.main: Explaining Bikini Girl’s Hair Color

abstract: Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time.
snippet: Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time.
lead_paragraph: Have you missed too many spur-of-the-moment shots with the digital camera because you had to wait for the company’s splash screen to go away when you turned the camera on? Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time. Just go to the camera’s menu or settings area and look for a “start-up screen” or similar option, then choose not to use it; check your camera’s manual for specific instructions. Within the camera’s menus, you should also be able to adjust the length of the review time each photo stays on the LCD screen after you snap it. By decreasing the time the last image stays on screen, you can get back to shooting photos more quickly. J. D. BIERSDORFER

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Disabling Your Camera’s Start-Up Screen

abstract: The Advertising column last Thursday, about a new campaign for Tropicana orange juice, misstated the amount of sugar in a 20-ounce bottle of Pepsi-Cola, which was compared to the amount of sugar in a 14-ounce carton of Tropicana. After nearly 50 years of marriage, they worked in the same Midtown Manhattan office, they traveled together, and they dined together night after night, just the two of them.

abstract: Amazon’s Universal Wish List button offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places.
snippet: Amazon’s Universal Wish List button offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places.
lead_paragraph: Even if you don’t do all your online shopping in the virtual megamall that is Amazon.com, the site offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places. With a simple one-time drag-and-drop move, Amazon’s Universal Wish List button, (available at www.amazon.com/gp/wishlist/get-button/), can be added to your browser’s toolbar. The next time you are out shopping on other sites  but are not quite ready to buy  click the Wish List button on the browser to save a link to the item to your personal Amazon Wish List. Clicking on the item later on the Wish List takes you back to the original store when you’re ready to get out the credit card.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Online Shopping Wish List

abstract: A modest proposal about a new government bank that would take over failing banks and then roll those banks back out again to shareholders once they are healthy.
snippet: A modest proposal about a new government bank that would take over failing banks and then roll those banks back out again to shareholders once they are healthy.
lead_paragraph: Anonymous Banker is back, one last time, with an idea to end the banking crisis. If you ask me, this idea isn’t any crazier than a lot of other ones being bandied about — and in fact, makes a lot more sense than most: create a new government bank that would take over failing banks and then roll those banks back out again — to the same set of shareholders! — when they becomes healthy and profitable again. I leave it to you, dear readers, to mull the pros and cons.

headline.main: The Central Bank: Anonymous Banker’s Solution to the Crisis

abstract: A few more ideas that came across my desk this week for solving the banking crisis.
snippet: A few more ideas that came across my desk this week for solving the banking crisis.
lead_paragraph: As I write in my column this week, I received a number of smart, interesting ideas for reviving the banking system. In the column, I elaborated on one: recreating some kind of Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created by the first President Bush to manage and sell the bad assets on the books of the banks during the S&L crisis. I do not pretend that it is a perfect solution — Tim Ryan, the former head of the Office of Thrift Supervision, who helped manage the country through that crisis, pointed out to me that the banking system is a lot more complicated than it was then. He also made the point that the O.T.C. had a mandate, by law, to take over insolvent S&Ls, while these days we quake at the thought of having the government take over a bank. “Nationalization” is a dirty word. If we could get past that, maybe we could get this problem fixed.

headline.main: Bring Back the R.T.C.!

lead_paragraph: There is an industry consensus that solid-state LED lights will play an increasingly important role in energy reduction programs. Light-emitting diodes use as little as one-tenth the power of an incandescent bulb, produce pleasing light and last for up to 20 years of normal use. abstract: Pfizer‘s $68 billion deal to buy the rival drug maker Wyeth ranks among the largest pharmaceutical deals of all time. The acquisition, which is being paid for in cash and Pfizer stock, also breaks a long-running drought in the merger world, which hasn’t seen such a large transaction (excluding spinoffs) since a group of banks bid nearly $96 billion for ABN Amro in April 2007.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer‘s $68 billion deal to buy the rival drug maker Wyeth ranks among the largest pharmaceutical deals of all time. The acquisition, which is being paid for in cash and Pfizer stock, also breaks a long-running drought in the merger world, which hasn’t seen such a large transaction (excluding spinoffs) since a group of banks bid nearly $96 billion for ABN Amro in April 2007.

abstract: It was not so long ago that most marketers steered clear of sponsoring TV programming that tackled the contentious subject of the lives of gay men and lesbians. How much that has changed was underlined on Saturday when Lifetime presented a two-hour movie, “Prayers for Bobby.”
snippet: It was not so long ago that most marketers steered clear of sponsoring TV programming that tackled the contentious subject of the lives of gay men and lesbians. How much that has changed was underlined on Saturday when Lifetime presented a two-hou...
lead_paragraph: It was not so long ago that most mainstream marketers steered clear of sponsoring television programming that tackled the contentious subject of the lives of gay men and lesbians. Large national advertisers, seeking to avoid alienating or offending mass audiences, would shy from buying commercial time during such shows. That left the slots to be filled with spots from companies that care less about the content of the programs in which they pitch products — or not filled at all.

headline.main: Buying ‘Bobby’

Ocala National Bank in Florida and Suburban Federal Savings Bank of Crofton, Md., were shut by federal regulators, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. MagnetBank of Salt Lake City was seized by the Utah Department of Financial Institutions. The banks had total assets of $876.4 million and deposits of $790 million.

abstract: Something terrible has happened in the U.S. economy. But a deeper look at the downturn, and the social changes it is bringing, shows a more complex picture.

lead_paragraph: AS job losses mount and bailout costs run into the trillions, the social costs of the economic downturn become clearer. The primary question, to be sure, is what can be done to shorten or alleviate these bad times. But there is also a broader set of questions about how this downturn is changing our lives, in ways beyond strict economics.

snippet: Theme clues include “that dress makes you look fat” and “onset of a lie” in this extra large Sunday crossword.
lead_paragraph: After two recent Sundays recognizing a new guy in the White House, today’s puzzle celebrates an event that all Americans, whether they hail from red Cardinal states or yellow and black Steeler states, can get behind. It’s time to set aside our differences, pick up our beer and potato chips, and focus on the one American activity that can unite us all in troubled times — wagering on sports championships.

headline.main: Grid-Irony

abstract: To really escape the crowds, it is best to avoid the wide, well groomed trails of the five-mountain Davos Klosters area and head for the back country.
snippet: To really escape the crowds, it is best to avoid the wide, well groomed trails of the five-mountain Davos Klosters area and head for the back country.
lead_paragraph: When the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting is over, Davos reverts to its normal self: a ritzy town at the heart of a world class ski area. The locals here, as much as they grumble about the WEF and its many inconveniences, tend to point out that this is a great time to go skiing because the mountains are empty as the town is bustling.

headline.main: Davos Off Piste: Getting Away from the Crowd
